BREACH OF PRIVILEGE
(Motion)


    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Ulu Pandan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move a motion regarding breach of privilege,

    That the Memorandum addressed to all Honourable Members of the Assembly dated 25th June, 1962, by the Chairman of the Singapore Trade Unions Working Committee (Committee of Liaison Officers of Trade Unions) contains threats to the Government back benchers in the following paragraphs:-

    "45. Everyone of you in the Assembly are responsible for whatever that might follow if a few dictators in power are allowed to have their way in snatching away from the people the rights that they have gained at the cost of bitter struggles and great sacrifices.

    "46. To those who are Government Backbenchers we wish to point out that it would be folly to think that they would not be held responsible by the people for the misdeeds of the Government leaders.

    "47. It is in fact in your hands to check the Government from its fascist moves. Indeed it is with the support of the Backbenchers that they have committed all their treacherous acts and can continue to do so only if they continue to support them.

    "48. Whatever happens the day is not far when the Government Backbenchers have to return to the people and live among them as ordinary men and women and for the rest of their life they will not be able to escape the people's reproach and wrath if they fail them now while those who are making use of these Backbenchers

REFERENDUM ON REUNIFICATION OF SINGAPORE
AND FEDERATION OF MALAYA


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Origial Question [9th July, 1962] as amended [10th July, l962],

    "That this House resolves that the people of Singapore be asked to express their choice on the mode and manner of the inevitable reunification of the two territories and that a referendum be held for the people to decide between the alternatives of reunification on the basis of

    (a) the constitutional arrangements set out in Paper Command 33 of 1961 giving Singapore autonomy in education and labour; or

    (b) a complete and unconditional merger as a state on an equal basis with the other eleven states in accordance with the constitutional documents of the Federation of Malaya; or

    (c) to enter Malaysia on terms no less favourable than the terms for the Borneo territories."

    Which Original Question was,

    "That this House resolves that the people of Singapore be asked to express their choice on the mode and manner of the inevitable reunification of the two territories and that a referendum be held for the people to decide between the alternatives of reunification on tha basis of

    (a) the constitutional arrangements set out in Paper Command 33 of 1961 giving Singapore autonomy in education and labour; or

    (b) a complete and unconditional merger as a state on an equal basis with the other eleven states in accordance with the constitutional documents of the Federation of Malaya.".-[The Prime Minister].

    Original Question, as amended, again proposed.

Column: 265



2.38 p.m.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, last week during the debate on the Singapore National. Referendum Bill enough evidence has been produced to show that the Barisan Sosialis do not want a referendum on merger. I will provide further evidence to show that the reason why they do not want a referendum is that they do not want merger between Singapore and the Federation, although they pay lip service to a merger policy.

    On 2nd June, 1961, leaders of the Barisan Sosialis issued a statement announcing that they advocated internal self-government for Singapore without the Internal Security Council and agreed to Defence and Foreign Affairs remaining in the hands of the British. This stand by the six Barisan leaders was ridiculed not only by us but also by the Member for Anson. Such a stand on the abolition of the Internal Security Council will bring practically no change to Singapore's constitutional development. In fact, it meant that the Barisan Sosialis was advocating the continuation of ---

    Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): On a point of guidance, Sir.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye resumed his seat.

    Mr Bani: May we know what the Deputy Prime Minister is now speaking on - whether it is on the original Question or the amendment itself?

    Mr Speaker: The Deputy Prime Minister is entitled to speak on the motion, as amended, the motion which I have proposed to the House.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I was saying, Mr Speaker, that this proposal by the six leaders of the Barisan Sosialis really meant a continuation of the semi-colonial status of Singapore. When this idea of the Barisan leaders was laughed at and ridiculed by the people, the Barisan Sosialis quickly changed their stand and thought out a new plan. And on 28th August, 1961, they issued a manifesto which was referred to by the Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis. The

Column: 266

Member for Queenstown, in a debate on the 18th April, 1962. I quote from the revised transcript of 18th April, 1962 [Vol. 17, No. 9, col. 888]:

    'Dr Lee Siew Choh: I bow to your ruling, Sir, and I will now, therefore, read to the House our document as issued by the Barisan Sosialis on the 28th August, 1961. That document is the stand of the Barisan Sosialis on our constitutional future. I will skip the irrelevant parts and go on to the part which follows the issue of Penang and Malacca. It reads as follows:

    "The way ahead for real reunification of our country and our people is in one of two directions:

    (a) an immediate, full and complete merger with Singapore joining the Federation as a constituent state like Penang or Malacca -"

those are the operative words -"

Let me repeat, "those are the operative words". Now, the stupidity of the Barisan Sosialis in advocating merger on the basis of Penang and Malacca was, in fact, pointed out as early as 23rd November, 1961, when during a debate on merger it was the Member for Anson who said - let me quote Hansard. Vol 15, No. 7, col. 574:

    `We will come to Penang and Malacca where the Barisan Sosialis, having no legal consultant, really slipped...'.

Mr Speaker, I suggest to you that the Barisan Sosialis slipped not because they had no legal consultant. In fact, when the 13 Barisan Assemblymen defected from the P.A.P., they also made great play that they had their own legal advisers; one of them was Mr T. T. Rajah.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): And a few more.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: The error of the Barisan Sosialis lies in the superficial manner in which they consider weighty problems of the State. It is fantastic indeed for a political Party like the Barisan to change its stand as easily as its leaders change their trousers!

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): How do you know they change their trousers?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: They might not have changed their trousers perhaps, but the Member for Cairnhill could perhaps investigate by the smell.

Column: 267



    Now, when we pointed out to the Barisan Sosialis that it was not possible for Singapore to merge with the Federation on the basis of Penang and Malacca, they refused to acknowledge the mistake. And finally it was left to the Member for Hong Lim to point out publicly this error in the thinking of the Barisan Sosialis. At the radio forum on 14th June, 1962, this was what the Member for Hong Lim said - let me quote:

    `Just now the Prime Minister has mentioned about the Barisan's stand of Penang and Malacca type of merger. My attitude towards this is that perhaps they have once made a mistake.'

    Yes, Mr Speaker, the Barisan has soiled its political trousers. We told them there was a stain on their trousers but they would not believe it. This was probably because we were sitting facing them. The Member for Anson and the Member for Hong Lim, being seated behind the Barisan Sosialis, could see the stain on the Barisan trousers more clearly. And they finally convinced the Barisan of their mistake. So it was that the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Anson succeeded in persuading the Barisan Sosialis to move a resolution for complete merger, even if it would mean the control of education and labour policies by the Central Government. In fact, the Member for Anson, during the debate last year on merger, was so excited at the prospect of having found an alliance in the Barisan Sosialis and so delighted that he had found a new formula that he had this to say (Hansard, Vol. 15, No. 7, col. 583):

    `Sir, I do not want to exaggerate. I cannot exaggerate. But I shall put it very simply. In fact, Sir, I will be quite frank that if education and labour were given to the Federation, the White Paper would be more acceptable to me, and I do not care if it means the end of my political career.'

Members of this House will remember the Member for Anson's public announcement that he was finished with politics after he had resigned as Chief Minister and failed to appear in a by-election in Cairnhill. We all know too well by now how much weight we can

Column: 268

attach to the words of the Member for Anson. The history of his political antics shows that he is one of the denizens of never, never land. Those who live in never, never land never, never mean what they say. The Member for Anson was so delighted that he had found an alliance in the Barisan Sosialis - continued in Hansard, Vol. 15, No. 7, col. 566:

    `Sir, I must say that I learned with some surprise and delight from the Member for Queenstown that his Party - to me, as far as I can understand, a Party that represents the industrial Chinese worker, I do not know about the others - were prepared to accept Federation control of education policy, and I say hear, hear!'

Now if the Barisan Sosialis, or for that matter the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Anson, are sincere about their declarations, then rightly they should go out and propagate to the people that they wish for complete merger with the Federation even if it means control of education and labour policies by the Central Government. But have they really done that? Mr Speaker, they have instead been spending their time in denouncing the referendum and the White Paper proposals. What is astounding is that the Barisan Sosialis should, within the space of one year, have changed its stand on merger three times. Three times! First, they wanted internal self-government without the Internal Security Council - the British to retain foreign affairs and defence. After this idea had been ridiculed by the people, they advocated merger like Penang and Malacca. When this new line was pointed out to them as a mistake by the Member for Anson and the Member for Hong Lim, they proposed in this House complete merger, even if it meant the control of education and labour policies by the Central Government.

    Mr Speaker, can the people of Singapore allow a political Party like the Barisan Sosialis to be in charge of the destiny of their future when such a political Party has no firm stand, no fixed policies and has no idea what constitutional changes mean to the livelihood of the people: a Party like the Barisan Sosialis which takes directives, from outside, which takes

Column: 269

directives or advice even from their opponents, the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Anson? Even the erstwhile revolutionaries in the Barisan Sosialis have lost confidence in their own Party and in their leadership. We know, Mr Speaker, that the Secretary-General of the Barisan Sosialis, Mr Lim Ching Siong, dispatched a mystery letter to the Prime Minister of the Federation, and by hand too. What the contents of this letter are, we do not know. I do not believe that any of the 13 Barisan Sosialis Assemblymen knows what is in this letter either.

    An hon. Member: Shame!

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Could it be another change in the stand of the Barisan Sosialis on merger? Or is this a secret sell-out? All these antics of the Barisan Sosialis clearly show their immaturity in the handling of public affairs. We dread to think of the consequences if the affairs of this country are allowed to: be managed by the Barisan Sosialis. The Barisan Sosialis can feed the people with slogans. But the people will remain hungry. What the people want is an assurance that they will have food to eat and water to drink. Not Barisan falsehoods and slogans rammed down their throats.

    Sir, two days ago, the Member for Anson made great play about the spirit of the Reid Constitutional Report. In fact, he had moved an amendment, which reads: 'merger as a state on an equal basis with the other eleven states with automatic Federation citizenship for all Singapore citizens in accordance with the spirit of the Reid Report and the constitutional documents of the Federation, 1948 and 1957.'

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not think the Deputy Prime Minister is right when he says that the amendment was moved. Notice was given but it was not moved.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Thank you, Mr Speaker, for the correction. The amendment was not moved, but notice of the amendment was given along these lines. The Member for Anson goes back to 1948 and 1957. But he forgets that we

Column: 270

are living in 1962. The spirit of the Reid Report is already embodied in the Constitution of the Federation of Malaya. This Constitution was gazetted on 11th December, 1957. In so far as those clauses relating to the admission of new territories and the question of citizenship by incorporation of territories are concerned, this Constitution still holds good. Article 2 of the Constitution says:

    `Parliament by law may admit other States to the Federation.'

And Article 22 states:

    `If any new territory is admitted to the Federation in pursuance of Article 2, Parliament may by law determine what, persons are to be citizens by reason of their connection with that territory and the date or dates from, which such persons are to be citizens.'

It means, in fact, that there is no question of automatic citizenship as demanded by the Barisan Sosialis, the Member for Anson and the Member for Hong Lim. Indeed, the Member for Anson argued that there was no provision for the transfer of automatic citizenship in the Federation Constitution. How those citizens who have connection with the territory that has joined the Federation after 1957 can become citizens of the Federation can only be decided by an Act of the Federation Parliament. This means that finally it is the Federation Government which must be responsible for passing this Act. Therefore, citizenship proposals must be negotiated with the Federation Government. To claim for automatic citizenship is quite contrary to the provisions of the Federation Constitution. To ask the people to vote for something for which no provision is made constitutionally is indeed to deceive the people. After he had spent considerable time reading the Report of the Reid Commission and arguing in its favour, we were indeed astounded that the Member for Anson announced, that he did not wish to move his amendment. The frivolity with which the Member for Anson introduces motions and withdraws them shows his utter disregard for other Members of this House. We therefore cannot regard him as a man to be considered seriously.

Column: 271



    If the Barisan Sosialis, the U.P.P. and the Workers' Party are honest in their intention for a closer relationship with the Federation, then they ought to adopt a more realistic attitude and seek to explain to the people what can really be achieved now instead of dangling objectives which they know very well cannot be obtained in the immediate future.

    Yesterday the Barisan Sosialis opposed the amendment of the Member for Cairnhill to add a third alternative in the proposals for the referendum. This proposal by the Member for Cairnhill suggested that Singapore should enter Malaysia on no less favourable terms than the Borneo territories. Let me remind the House that during the debate on merger, one of the points which the Barisan Sosialis harped upon was that whereas the Federation was prepared to accept the Borneo territories as constituent States of the Federation. Singapore was being treated on a less favourable level. In fact, in their argument they suggested, that Singapore should be treated at par with the Borneo territories. It was surprising indeed that the Member for Queenstown, the Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis, should have opposed the entry of Singapore into Malaysia on no less favourable terms than the Borneo territories. This stand of the Barisan Sosialis can be explained in the light of our knowledge of their opposition towards the formation of Malaysia. The Barisan Sosialis do not want Malaysia. Neither do they want Singapore to enter Malaysia. Why, Sir? The reason is that the Barisan Sosialis are following the line of the P.K.I., the Communist Party of Indonesia, which opposes the Malaysia Plan. During the debate on West Irian, the Member for Thomson let the cat out of the bag why the Barisan was against Malaysia. Mr Speaker. I could not get hold of a copy of Hansard for this debate, and I have to resort to newspaper reports of this debate. This was what the Straits Times of 20th January, 1962 (page 4) had to say:

    `He [Mr Bani] said Malaysia was an anti-Indonesia plan. Mr David Marshall asked if

Column: 272

Mr Bani would explain what he meant when he said that Malaysia was an anti-Indonesia plan.

    Mr Bani continued: "We have been accused of being anti-Malaysia. Our attitude is quite simple. We support the concept of Malaysia."

    He said that an original plan for Malaysia had included Indonesia, but the plan of Tunku Abdul Rahman excluded Indonesia.'.

    The Member for Thomson cannot deny saying that Malaysia was anti-Indonesia because it did not include Indonesia. In fact, during the debate on Malaysia, the Member for Anson vigorously protested against this stand of the Barisan Sosialis. I quote from the Straits Times of the 25th of January, 1962, page 12:

    `Referring to a statement made by Mr S. T. Barn (Barisan-Thomson) during the debate on West Irian that Malaysia was anti-Indonesia, Mr David Marshall said he could not accept this.

    "To say that the Malaysia Plan was anti-Indonesia could suggest only one thing, that the Barisan Sosialis considered the North Borneo territories should be part of Indonesia and not part of Malaysia."'

    Sir, ever since the Assembly and the people of Singapore became involved in the question of merger and Malaysia, the conspiracies of the Barisan Sosialis to prevent and hinder merger to stop Malaysia have been exposed. They are an utterly insincere and dishonest group of people who do not have the national interest at heart, but only seek ---

    Mr Bani: Bluff!

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: --- to promote the interest of the Communist movement in South-East Asia ---

    An hon. Member: Do not bluff yourself!

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: It hurts them, Mr Speaker. As stooges of the P.K.I., they are prepared to stoop to the strategy of fighting the referendum, fighting merger and Malaysia and all this against the national interest of Singapore, the Federation and the Borneo territories. In this very debate itself, the Barisan Sosialis in their last desperate moments once more reveal with ease the fluidity with which they change their stand. They move one

Column: 273

amendment to the motion we are debating. But even before a vote had been taken on this amendment, the leader of the Barisan Sosialis, the Member for Queenstown, indicated that his Party would introduce another amendment.

    Sir, the antics of the Barisan Sosialis are of no avail, because the people have no confidence in their Party which seeks to remove the British ---

    Mr Bani: Why do you not try ---

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Let me repeat it so that they can hear it better. The antics of the Barisan Sosialis are of no avail because the people have no confidence in their Party which seeks to remove British colonialism in order to substitute another type of foreign imperialism.

    Mr Bani: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move an amendment ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. May I just remind the hon. Member that he may speak on the motion as well, because he is now speaking on the main motion. He will not have another opportunity of speaking on the main motion. At the same time, he can move the amendment.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): I seek your guidance, Sir. Can I speak again on this?

    Mr Speaker: I am afraid not. The procedure is that the Member for Queenstown when he moved his amendment was speaking on the main motion. Therefore, he is now prohibited from speaking again on the main motion. The Member for Thomson has not done so as yet. The Member for Cairnhill has spoken on the main motion when he moved his amendment. The Deputy Prime Minister has spoken on the main motion. And now the Member for Thomson is speaking on the main motion. Any Member who has not as yet spoken on the main motion may do so. But there is nothing to prevent those Members from speaking on any amendments that may be moved now.

Column: 274



    Mr Bani: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, as an amendment,

    "at end, to add `or

    (d) genuine merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth state and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal Citizens on Merger Day'.".

    Sir, this amendment will put forth in the referendum a proposition which, in fact, will be the stand of the Barisan Sosialis on the merger issue ---

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Another stand, is it?

    Mr Bani: Sir, I do not wish to comment on what the Deputy Prime Minister has said at this juncture ---

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: You had better not.

    Mr Bani: --- and he will get his answers in good time. The only direct comment that I want to make is that I am sure he does not believe half of what he has said just now.

    Sir, this concept of merger has been supported by the Workers' Party and the United People's Party in this Assembly in November last year. I refer you. Mr Speaker, to col. 406 of the debate of 21st November, 1961. You will note, Sir, that the proposition I now make to be put to the people is, in fact, word for word, the same as the amendment moved on 21st November, 1961, to the P.A.P. Government motion on the reunification of the two territories. You will recall, Sir, that this amendment was opposed by the P.A.P. and was subsequently defeated in this Assembly. Sir, the sentiments on this amendment have been thoroughly discussed in the debate held last year. Our points of view have been explained clearly and they are in black and white in the records of the Assembly. I do not propose to repeat them.

    Sir, it has been said that the Barisan Sosialis made a mistake in asking for complete merger.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: He thinks of getting complete merger.

Column: 275



    Mr Bani: Government Members, to substantiate their allegation, have attempted to quote the Member for Hong Lim as though he is an authority on Barisan affairs, as saying that we had made a mistake ---

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Certainly, the Barisan ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. May I ask the Deputy Prime Minister not to interject so often?

    Mr Bani: To some extent, Sir, they have also tried to quote the Member for Anson. But, as you are aware, Mr Speaker. Sir, the Member for Anson has refuted this. Today the P.A.P. use half truths and untruths to keep this afloat. The Member for Hong Lim once used an analogy of the Johore type of merger. Sir, the P.A.P. has twisted that to mean that he wants the Johore type of merger. Sir, I do not want to suggest that the Menther for Hong Lim has made a mistake. In all fairness to him, I must say he merely made the analogy in the context of a speech that he was making. But the desperate P.A.P. have tried to use that to make political capital. The Member for Hong Lim unwittingly played into the P.A.P. hands. Sir, we must correct this and straighten it out once and for all. There is no question of a mistake by the Barisan. Sir, we have stated in the past very clearly that we want merger. We have stated that we want complete merger. We have stated that we want a merger which is genuine and which can bring about genuine national unity. We have also stated that, in our view, merger arrangements which will create different classes of citizens, which will only further the disunity among our people and which will deny the people of Singapore a common political life with their brothers and sisters in the Federation, will not constitute genuine merger and will not bring about genuine national unity. There is no mistake about this, Mr Speaker. The records show clearly our stand. Because today the P.A.P. are politically bankrupt, they seek to distort and use half truths and untruths to defend their actions which are detrimental to national unity. Therefore, Sir, they have

Column: 276

sought to use our analogy of Penang and Malacca, to use this completely out of context is order to distort our stand, because they hope by doing this they will show that our proposition will mean the disfranchisement of half of our citizens. They seek to discredit us by saying that we want half of our citizens to lose their citizenship rights. They have done this in the same way as they attempted to distort the analogy of Johore which was used by the Member for Hong Lim.

    Sir, there is no mistake as I have already stated. We have clearly asked for genuine merger with all Singapore citizens automatically becoming Federal citizens on merger. Just now, Mr Speaker, Sir, while the Deputy Prime Minister was speaking, he sought to suggest that the call for complete internal self-government was inconsistent with the stand of the Barisan Sosialis on the merger issue. Sir, I do not want to start the debate on the whole question of reunification all over again. We have dealt with this matter at great length in the debate on the question of merger in this House last year. This cheap tactic of the P.A.P. to try and distort is not going to help them one wee bit.

    Sir, they say that we are communal in our approach and yet they seek to harp on autonomy in labour and education. They say that the Barisan made a mistake by asking for complete merger, because in a complete merger there will be no autonomy in education and labour. Sir, in all honesty, if the Government Members would admit, they would say that this is directed at the Chinese population in Singapore, and they have the cheek to stand up and say that it is the Barisan Sosialis that is playing the Chinese line.

    As I said, I have no intention of re-opening the debate on the whole question of merger. We have debated it at great length and our conscience is clear because we have no dirt to hide. As I also said, we are not the least perturbed at all these twists and turns, at all these lies and distortions of the P.A.P.

    Sir, the Prime Minister said that what the Government offer are realistic alternatives. We dispute this, Mr Speaker,

Column: 277

Sir. Our people should not be compelled to choose one of these alternatives simply because the P.A.P. consider them realistic. What the P.A.P. consider realistic is not necessarily good for our people. It is not interest of national reunification. When the P.A.P. say that these alternatives are realistic, what they do, in fact, mean is necessarily in the that these are terms which are acceptable to the Government of the Federation of Malaya. Surely, Sir, what the Federation is prepared to accept is not necessarily good for the people of Singapore; it is not necessarily fair to the people of Singapore.

    Sir, we in the Barisan Sosialis refuse to accept the position where merger terms for Singapore are dictated by a handful of people in the Federation of Malaya. The fate of the people of Singapore should not be made to depend on the charity of a few men who hold power in their hands in the Federation.

    Sir, merger must mean genuine national reunification of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya. It must mean the genuine national unity of our people. This cannot be achieved if the people of Singapore are going to be treated as slaves.

    Sir, the P.A.P. say, "Merger now or never."

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): I never said that. "Merger now or later." There will be merger.

    Mr Bani: They say that if there is to be no merger now there will be no merger forever. The Prime Minister obviously denies this.
